hm.binkley.util

Class Converter

  • java.lang.Object
    • hm.binkley.util.Converter

  • public final class Converter
extends Object
    Converter is the opposite of toString(). It turns strings into objects. Useful, for example, when obtaining Java value types from XML.

    Supports registered types explicitly with default registered conversions:

    • Class
    • InetAddress
    • InetSocketAddress
    • Path
    • Pattern
    • Resource
    • List of Resources
    • ResourceBundle
    • TimeZone
    • URI

    Supports other types implicitly by looking for a single-argument string factory method or constructor in this order:

    1. Factory method parse(String)
    2. Factory method valueOf(String)
    3. Factory method of(String)
    4. Constructor T(String)
    5. Constructor T(CharSequence)
    Author:
    B. K. Oxley (binkley)
    See Also:
    register(Class, Conversion), register(TypeToken, Conversion)
    Pending:
    Remove duplication with xprop, Discuss concurrency safety, Do factory methods need to consider CharSequence?

      • register

        public <T> void register(@Nonnull
                         Class<T> type,
                         @Nonnull
                         Converter.Conversion<T,?> factory)
                  throws Converter.DuplicateConversion
        Registers an object conversion. Use this for plain types without consideration of generics.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the conversion type
        Parameters:
        type - the class token, never missing
        factory - the converter, never missing
        Throws:
        Converter.DuplicateConversion - if the conversion is already registered

      • register

        public <T> void register(@Nonnull
                         com.google.common.reflect.TypeToken<T> type,
                         @Nonnull
                         Converter.Conversion<T,?> factory)
                  throws Converter.DuplicateConversion
        Registers an object conversion. Use this for types with generics, for example, collections.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the conversion type
        Parameters:
        type - the Guava type token, never missing
        factory - the converter, never missing
        Throws:
        Converter.DuplicateConversion - if the conversion is already registered

      • registerDate

        public void registerDate(@Nonnull
                         String pattern)
        Registers a date format pattern for legacy java.util.Date. By default Converter uses the deprecated Date.Date(String) constructor.

        This method is a convenience and a caution for surprising legacy date parsing. Better is to use java.time classes.

        Parameters:
        pattern - the date format pattern, never missing

      • registered

        @Nonnull
public Set<com.google.common.reflect.TypeToken<?>> registered()
        Get an unmodifiable view of registered conversions. Supported conversions are those implicit and those registered; registered takes precedence.
        Returns:
        the set of registered conversion types, never missing
        Pending:
        What is the best way to expose conversions for inspection/management?
